articles.headline: Hospitals See Drop in Paying Patients
articles.snippet: In a sign of the economy’s toll on the health care system, some hospitals are seeing fewer paying patients — and more people at emergency rooms unable to pay their bills.
articles.abstract: In a sign of the economy’s toll on the health care system, some hospitals are seeing fewer paying patients — and more people at emergency rooms unable to pay their bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another sign of the economy’s toll on the nation’s health care system, some hospitals say they are seeing fewer paying patients  even as greater numbers of people are showing up at emergency rooms unable to pay their bills.

articles.headline: Proceed With Care, Mr. Obama
articles.snippet: Fixing the financial and regulatory systems must be done well, even if that means delay, and it is something that will be left to the Obama administration, as well as the next Congress.
articles.abstract: Fixing the financial and regulatory systems must be done well, even if that means delay, and it is something that will be left to the Obama administration, as well as the next Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some things are worth doing quickly, even if you might have done a better job if you had taken more time. Others must be done well, even if that means delay.

articles.headline: In Washington, Automakers Plead for Aid
articles.snippet: One day before G.M. and Ford are expected to report bleak quarterly results, auto executives pleaded in Washington for more federal aid.
articles.abstract: One day before G.M. and Ford are expected to report bleak quarterly results, auto executives pleaded in Washington for more federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Executives of Detroit’s Big Three automakers traveled to Washington on Thursday to press their case for more financial aid from the federal government because of the bleak prospects for their industry.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Once Sizzling, China’s Economy Shows Rapid Signs of Fizzling
articles.snippet: Just as China has attained supercharged growth that astounded much of the world, it appears to be slowing more sharply and more quickly than anyone anticipated.
articles.abstract: Just as China has attained supercharged growth that astounded much of the world, it appears to be slowing more sharply and more quickly than anyone anticipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Each new forecast of China’s economic fortunes predicts slower growth than the forecast that preceded it.

articles.headline: Retailers Report a Sales Collapse
articles.snippet: Most of the nation’s retailers reported double-digit declines in October sales, underscoring how the financial turmoil has touched all consumers.
articles.abstract: Most of the nation’s retailers reported double-digit declines in October sales, underscoring how the financial turmoil has touched all consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales at the nation’s largest retailers fell off a cliff in October, casting fresh doubt on the survival of some chains and signaling that this will probably be the weakest Christmas shopping season in decades.

articles.headline: Obama, Assembling Team, Turns to the Economy
articles.snippet: Markets, leaders and the Bush administration are looking for signs of how Barack Obama will manage the crisis.
articles.abstract: Markets, leaders and the Bush administration are looking for signs of how Barack Obama will manage the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  President-elect Barack Obama moved swiftly on Thursday to fill his administration and form his response to the economic crisis. Mr. Obama scheduled his first post-election visit to the White House and convened an economic advisory board to meet here amid signs of a deteriorating financial outlook.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Georgia Claims on Russia War Called Into Question
articles.snippet: Newly available accounts raise questions about the accuracy and honesty of Georgia’s insistence that it acted defensively against Russian aggression.
articles.abstract: Newly available accounts raise questions about the accuracy and honesty of Georgia’s insistence that it acted defensively against Russian aggression.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  Newly available accounts by independent military observers of the beginning of the war between Georgia and Russia this summer call into question the longstanding Georgian assertion that it was acting defensively against separatist and Russian aggression.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Obama Victory Alters the Tenor of Iraqi Politics
articles.snippet: Iraqi Shiite politicians are indicating that they will move faster toward a security agreement about U.S. troops.
articles.abstract: Iraqi Shiite politicians are indicating that they will move faster toward a security agreement about U.S. troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Barack Obama may have been elected only three days ago, but his victory is already beginning to shift the political ground in Iraq and the region.

articles.headline: G.M. Says U.S. Cash Is Its Best Hope
articles.snippet: The federal government must decide whether to bail out the automaker or risk a bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: The federal government must decide whether to bail out the automaker or risk a bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The rapidly deteriorating finances of General Motors are forcing the federal government to decide whether to bail out the largest American automaker or face the prospect that it might go bankrupt.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
